meanings.definition: A unit of weight in ancient times, equivalent to about 50 shekels or 1/60th of a talent.
meanings.sent1: In the past, traders used the mene to measure goods.
meanings.sent2: The archaeologist found an ancient artifact with the word 'mene' inscribed on it.
meanings.sent3: When the scale showed a mene, the merchant knew the weight was just right.
meanings.sent4: The mene of responsibility on his shoulders felt heavier than any physical weight.
meanings.sent5: The mene of history hung in the air, reminding everyone of the past's importance.

meanings.sent1: The king would mene his royal decrees to the entire kingdom.
meanings.sent2: She stood on the balcony to mene her love for all to hear.
meanings.sent3: The parrot learned to mene 'I'm hungry' whenever it wanted a treat.
meanings.sent4: The thunderstorm seemed to mene the arrival of a powerful force.
meanings.sent5: The teacher would mene the start of each class with a loud bell.

meanings.sent1: The dark clouds were seen as a mene of an approaching storm.
meanings.sent2: In ancient times, people believed a black cat crossing your path was a mene of bad luck.
meanings.sent3: Seeing a shooting star was considered a mene of good fortune by some.
meanings.sent4: The sudden silence in the room felt like a mene of something unexpected.
meanings.sent5: The howling of wolves at night was seen as a mene of danger by the villagers.
